docs.lead_paragraph: The Aon Corporation, the world's No. 2 insurance broker, said yesterday that it would spin off its insurance underwriting operations in a move to build up that business and remove potential conflicts with its brokerage operations. Aon, which is based in Chicago and ranks behind the Marsh & McLennan Companies, said the new company, to be spun off to existing shareholders, would combine Aon's five underwriting units, which specialize in accident, health and warranty insurance.

headline.main: AON, INSURANCE BROKER, IS PLANNING A SPINOFF

docs.abstract: Aon Corp, world's second-largest insurance broker, will spin off its underwriting operations (S)
docs.snippet: The Aon Corporation, the world's No. 2 insurance broker, said yesterday that it would spin off its insurance underwriting operations in a move to build up that business and remove potential conflicts with its brokerage operations. Aon, which is based...

docs.lead_paragraph: More than 100 graduates of Columbia University's nursing program gathered yesterday for a reunion, but they did not meet on Columbia property. Columbia made it clear that they were not welcome, so they met on the 10th floor of the New York Athletic Club, on Central Park South. Their sin, according to Columbia, is that they are unreasonably independent; they want to steer their own course rather than follow the lead of the university. More specifically, Columbia feels the Columbia University-Presbyterian Hospital School of Nursing Alumni Association Inc., which has an impressive $6 million bank account, has been collecting $25 dues from the same pool of 8,000 nursing graduates that Columbia wants to tap, thus getting in the way of the Columbia nursing school's efforts to raise money.

headline.main: Still Alma Mater, but More Distant

docs.abstract: Rift develops between Columbia University and graduates of its nursing school, whose alumni association collects and invests dues from its members that Columbia feels it impedes its own fund-raising efforts; photo (M)
docs.snippet: More than 100 graduates of Columbia University's nursing program gathered yesterday for a reunion, but they did not meet on Columbia property. Columbia made it clear that they were not welcome, so they met on the 10th floor of the New York Athletic...

docs.lead_paragraph: Mark Green arrived at the sunlit art gallery in Bedford-Stuyvesant just after all of the pieces had fallen into place. His mayoral campaign aides had successfully summoned television and newspaper reporters. Robert F. Kennedy Jr., son of the New York senator who 35 years ago helped set up the complex in Brooklyn that houses the gallery, accompanied him.

headline.main: In Mayor's Race, Campaigning Is Blended With Official Duties

docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: More than $1 billion of H.M.O. claims will not be paid promptly enough to comply with a New Jersey law this year, according to a study released yesterday by an association of doctors in the state. The study tracked 17,500 claim forms over a week in January and found that 90 percent of the managed health care market violated the state's ''prompt payment'' law 25 percent of the time. Under the law, which was passed in 1999, H.M.O.'s must process electronically filed claims within 30 days and paper claims within 40 days.

headline.main: H.M.O.'s Late In Paying Many Claims, Study Finds

docs.lead_paragraph: NORTHWEST WASHINGTON: STATE WORKERS WALK OUT State workers conducted a second day of ''rolling walkouts'' to press for bigger raises from the Legislature. The partial strikes by the Washington Federation of State Employees, the largest union of state employees, disrupted three ports as longshoremen honored the picket lines of grain inspectors. Picket lines also went up at some schools and hospitals, though the union says strikes will not affect services like food delivery and health care. Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT) MIDWEST ILLINOIS: POLICING LENDERS Legislators have endorsed regulations on so-called predatory lending, responding to a rash of home foreclosures in Chicago. Several large banks support the rules, which were proposed by Gov. George Ryan after reports that poor people had been charged $15,000 to refinance a $29,000 loan. The vote cleared the way for the rules to take effect May 17. They will cap fees at 6 percent of a loan, require disclosure of credit insurance and prohibit the refinancing of loans with no benefit to consumers. Bill Dedman (NYT)

docs.lead_paragraph: UnitedHealth Group, a leading health insurer, said yesterday that it would manage pharmacy services for more than 1.6 million members of AARP, generating about $350 million in annual revenue for the company. The contract between UnitedHealth's Ovations unit and AARP and AARP Services Inc. is effective June 1, UnitedHealth said. The insurer, based in Minnetonka, Minn., already provides supplemental Medicare and hospital indemnity insurance to 3.6 million people through an AARP program.

headline.main: UNITEDHEALTH TO MANAGE PHARMACY SERVICES FOR AARP

docs.lead_paragraph: The California Public Employees' Retirement System approved a health-insurance package today that includes a 6 percent premium increase and requires members to pay more when they buy drugs or see a doctor.

docs.lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about a commitment by the Kaiser Permanente health maintenance organization in California to improve access to health care for people with disabilities misspelled the surname of the medical director of Kaiser's Riverside hospital, who commented. He is Dr. Michael Neri, not Meri.

docs.lead_paragraph: For 25 years, environmental groups and state officials have concentrated on the problems posed by toxic PCB's in the Hudson River, but now they are starting to focus on dozens of contaminated spots in landfills and backyards in the upper Hudson Valley. More than six times as many PCB's were dumped on land as in the river, according to two separate investigations conducted by environmental groups and based on state records. Although the chemicals are not as dangerous on land as they are in the river, where they become concentrated in fish and river sediment, they are seeping into groundwater in a number of places, and may be leaking into the Hudson in a few, according to state officials.

headline.main: PCB Worries Are Spreading From Hudson To Its Shores

docs.abstract: Enviromental groups and state officials start to focus on landfills and other shore areas contaminated by PCB's; state records show more than six times as many PCB's were dumped on land as in Hudson River and, while not as dangerous on land, there is concern that they are seeping into groundwater and may be leaking into river; 13 of approximately 40 dumping sites within 40 miles of Albany have been designated as significant threat to public health or environment by State Dept of Environmental Conservation; could become huge liability for General Electric, which dumped chemical and is now waging public relations war against dredging Hudson River; photo (M)
docs.snippet: For 25 years, environmental groups and state officials have concentrated on the problems posed by toxic PCB's in the Hudson River, but now they are starting to focus on dozens of contaminated spots in landfills and backyards in the upper Hudson...

docs.lead_paragraph: Surgeons, the medical masters of the universe, are not noted for their willingness to cooperate. So it is no surprise that the operating room at Armstrong County Memorial Hospital used to stock five different hip joint implants, a favorite model for each of its orthopedic surgeons. Implant prices could range widely, from $4,000 to $6,000, and for years, no one seemed to care. But that was before Armstrong, the only hospital in this rural and coal mining county 38 miles north of Pittsburgh, slid into a financial black hole and faced the likelihood of closing or being sold to outsiders.

headline.main: HEALING A HOSPITAL: A special report.; Alternative Medicine for Ailing Institution

docs.abstract: Special report, Healing A Hospital, describes how one community hospital tackled its severe financial problems and stayed open, at time when most of nation's hospitals are ailing and many are closing; Armstrong County Memorial Hospital in Kittanning, Pa, 186-bed facility, hired turnaround expert as interim chief; he cut all salaries, dismissed some workers, reduced employees' time of by one vacation week and one holiday, and started search for new chief executive; new chief executive quickly hired financial analyst to clean up hospital's books; contracts with doctors were reviewed and tightened and bills to Medicare and managed care companies were checked for accuracy and completeness; number of board members was halved and those remaining were given training course in governance and strategic planning; new board hired salaried doctors to operate primary care centers around county, and those doctors referred many patients to Armstrong; many of moves have been painful and difficult, but result is that hospital has run surpluses in three of last four years, after losing $2.2 million in 1995; photos; graphs (L)
